notes.1:
ED H&P Note

MRN: 5678912

Natalie  Morgan

09/18/2023

The patient is a 35-year-old woman who presents to the Emergency Department with a cat bite wound that developed into cellulitis ***

SUBJECTIVE: ***

Patient does not have any known medical history. However she reported 3 days post cat bite wound, her arm started to show signs of redness and swelling and felt warm to touch. No family history suggestive of any genetic disorders or interesting presentations.

The patient leads a generally healthy lifestyle with no record of smoking, alcohol, or drug use. 

Non-allergic to any known pharmacological substances. Not on any daily medication.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
General:  No fevers, chills, productive cough, excessive weight gain or weight loss.
HEENT:  Negative.
RESPIRATORY:  No lung problems.  No paroxsymal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, or shortness of breath.
CARDIAC:  No chest pain, chest pressure, or anginal symptoms.
GASTROINTESTINAL/GENITOURINARY:  No gastrointestinal or genitourinary problems. No polyuria or polydipsia.  No kidney or liver problems.
HEMATOLOGIC/LYMPHATICS:  No bleeding dyscrasias or blood emesis.
NEUROLOGICAL:  No transient ischemic attack or cerebrovascular accident.  No vertigo, syncope, or loss of consciousness.
PSYCHOLOGY:  Patient has no signs or symptoms of depression.
SKIN:  Open lesion on the arm due to cat bite.

OBJECTIVE:

Vital signs stable.

GENERAL: Alert, oriented, appears comfortable
HEENT: PERRLA. Conjunctivae pink.  Tongue midline.  Oral mucosa pink and moist.
NECK:  Supple.  No groin, neck, or axillary lymphadenopathy.  No thyromegaly.
RESPIRATORY:  Lungs clear.  Respiratory effort unlabored.
CARDIAC:  No jugular venous distention or carotid bruits.  Regular rate and rhythm.  No murmurs, gallops, or rub.  PMI within normal limits.  No edema.  Pedal pulses +2.  No femoral bruits.
GASTROINTESTINAL:  Abdomen nontender.  Active bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly.
MUSCULOSKELETAL:  Gait steady.  Strength is equal in all extremities. 
SKIN:  Admitted with a visible lesion on arm, due to a cat bite. Area around the wound showed signs of inflammation. Warm and dry.
NEUROLOGICAL:  Cranial nerves II-XII grossly intact.  No numbness or tingling in the extremities.

ASSESSMENT/PLAN
Acute condition - Cat bite wound that has developed into cellulitis. Developing sepsis due to bacterial infection. IV antibiotics have been started along with IV fluids. The patient's condition requires constant monitoring.

The patient will be continuously monitored. Infusion of crystalloids via intravenous fluids and antibiotics to manage the sepsis will be ongoing.

TREATMENTCALENDAR:
  09/18/2023 - Start of IV fluids and IV antibiotic therapy. The response to therapy is to be evaluated daily.
notes.2: Patient Natalie Morgan, a 35-year-old female, has been hospitalized following from a serious cat bite wound that had resulted in the development of cellulitis. She was bitten by a stray cat several days before she reported to emergency. In the following days, her arm began to show signs of infection, including redness, swelling, and increased temperature. Upon further evaluation and testing, it was revealed that she was suffering from a bacterial infection and was possibly developing sepsis. As a result, she was immediately given intravenous fluids and antibiotics. Due to severity of the condition, she requires ongoing monitoring of her vital signs and continuous intravenous antibiotic treatment in the hospital. Her mental health status has not been mentioned, however, potential stress or anxiety caused due to this sudden medical event should be considered in her overall treatment plan to ensure her well-being during the hospital stay..
notes.3:
Department: Emergency Medicine

Chief Complaint: 
HPI: Natalie Morgan, a 35-year-old female, arrived at the ER with a visible lesion on her arm, exhibiting signs of inflammation. She reported being bitten by a stray cat three days prior to her visit. Pain, edema, and reddening of the bitten area ensued. She has no known allergies or acute medical issues, and adopts a generally healthy lifestyle.

Assessment/Differential Diagnosis: The patient's presentation and history revealed One La developing cellulitis from the cat bite wound, and a laboratory-confirmed bacterial infection. Given the severity of her condition, she's constantly monitored for possible sepsis progression.  
   
ED Course/Medical Decision Making: Continuous monitoring of the patient's vitals, and Initiation of IV fluids and antibiotics were undertaken based on the diagnosis.

Pre-Hospital/Procedures/Consults: Prior to hospital admission, no treatments or consultations were reported.

Disposition: Given the severity, further assessment and treatment within an inpatient setting was deemed necessary.
  
Past Medical History: The patient does not have any known medical history. She does not smoke, consume alcohol, or illicit drugs. 

Family History: No known genetic disorders or other relevant health issues noted.

Social History: The patient practices a generally healthy lifestyle without any vices.

Allergies: The patient has no known allergies to any medication.

Vital Signs: Stable upon physical examination.

Physical Exam: Upon examination, the patient was conscious, alert, and oriented. Observation of the lesion on her arm showed signs of inflammation indicating infection. The rest of the systems examined did not reveal any additional significant findings.

Lab Observations: In light of the suspected sepsis, laboratory tests were carried out which confirmed a bacterial infection.

ED Medications Ordered: The patient was promptly started on antibiotics via IV alongside fluid therapy.

In conclusion, continuous clinical care and monitoring of Ms. Morgan's condition are crucial, including reassessment of her response to the current antibiotic and fluid therapies. Regular monitoring of laboratory values will help assess the effectiveness of the treatment and the presence of potential complications, specifically the risk of progressing septicemia. New evaluations should be considered if symptoms do not improve or worsen. These may deeply impact her treatment plans moving forward.

MRN

Natalie Morgan

09/18/2023

Chief Complaint: Rapid worsening of cat bite wound, cellulitis ***


SUBJECTIVE: 

Past Medical History: No known medical history 

Past Surgical History: No known surgical history

Family History: No known genetic disorders or other relevant health issues 

Social History: Non-smoker, non-drinker, no illicit drug use.

Allergies: No known drug allergies.

Current Medications: None prior to this encounter.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
General: Fevers and swelling.  
HEENT: Normal
RESPIRATORY: No lung problems.  No paroxsymal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, or shortness of breath.
CARDIAC: Stable, no chest pain, chest pressure, or anginal symptoms.
GASTROINTESTINAL/GENITOURINARY: Normal
HEMATOLOGIC/LYMPHATICS: No bleeding dyscrasias or blood emesis.
NEUROLOGICAL: Normal
PSYCHOLOGY: Alert and oriented.
SKIN: Open lesion on arm- cat bite wound, red, hot, swollen.


OBJECTIVE:

Vital signs: Stable

GENERAL: Febrile and swollen arm. 
HEENT: PERRLA. Conjunctivae pink.  Tongue midline.  Oral mucosa pink and moist.
NECK:  Supple.  No thyromegaly.
RESPIRATORY:  Lungs clear.  Respiratory effort unlabored.
CARDIAC: Regular rate, rhythm, no murmurs 
GASTROINTESTINAL:  No hepatosplenomegaly.
MUSCULOSKELETAL: Confirmed acute pain in swollen arm upon physical examination 
SKIN: Open wound, exhibiting signs of cellulitis- hot, red, swollen
NEUROLOGICAL: Grossly intact 

ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
Cellulitis from a cat bite, laboratory confirmed bacterial infection graduating towards sepsis mediated by the bacterial infection. Antibiotics initiated via IV along with supportive international fluids. Continuous monitoring of the patient's vitals to note changes indicative of increased sepsis severity. 

ORDERS: Continue with IV antibiotics and revaluate in a few hours based on response to current treatment. Scheduled tests to monitor bacterial infection.

TREATMENT CALENDAR: Initiated on 09/18/2023 ongoing
notes.5:
Internal Medicine Progress Note

MRN

Natalie Morgan

09/18/2023

Chief Complaint: Progression of cellulitis from a cat bite wound***

SUBJECTIVE: 

Past Medical History: No known medical history 

Past Surgical History: No known surgical history

Family History: No known genetic disorders or other relevant health issues 

Social History: Non-smoker, non-drinker, no illicit drug use.

Allergies: No known drug allergies.

Current Medications: IV antibiotics initiated on 09/18/2023

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
General: Fevers, significant arm swelling
HEENT: Normal
RESPIRATORY: Regular breathwork, no dyspnea 
CARDIAC: Stable cardiac profile, no chest pain
GASTROINTESTINAL/GENITOURINARY: Normal
HEMATOLOGIC/LYMPHATICS: Normal bleeding profile
NEUROLOGICAL: Cognitive functionality normal
PSYCHOLOGY: Mentally alert and conscious.
SKIN: Cat bite wound visible, severe redness and swelling observed, warmth from inflammation perceived

OBJECTIVE:

Vital signs: Stable, sepsis diagnosis validated by lab reports

GENERAL: Patient is febrile with visible wound inflammation
HEENT: Normal
RESPIRATORY: Normal respiratory rate 
CARDIAC: Regular heart rate and rhythm
GASTROINTESTINAL: Abdominal profile normal
MUSCULOSKELETAL: Arm wound evidently causes discomfort and pain
SKIN: Localized cellulitis around cat bite wound 
NEUROLOGICAL: Neural examination is normal

ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
Ms. Morgan's wound from a cat bite has manifested into cellulitis and there are corroborated lab indications of bacterial infection. The immediate concern is a developing sepsis condition and she is currently being given IV antibiotics to mitigate and counter this.
Current plan constitutes the rigorous evaluation of her medical reports and contingent adjustment of the treatment plan, including the potential switching or advancing of antibiotics, should there be a lack of observed progress with the present approach.

ORDERS: Continue course of IV antibiotics. Regular reporting of lab results to monitor the dynamics of the bacterial infection.

TREATMENT CALENDAR: Initiated on 09/18/2023 ongoing

Patient has strong understanding of her condition and current course of treatment. Consent for ongoing treatment provided, and relative follow-ups scheduled.
notes.6:
ED H&P Note

MRN: 

Natalie Morgan

09/18/2023

Chief Complaint: Acute Cellulitis from a cat bite wound***

SUBJECTIVE: 

Past Medical History: The patient is not reported to have any medical history 

Past Surgical History: The patient has no surgical history

Family History: There are no known genetic disorders or relevant health issues in the family.

Social History: Natalie is a non-smoker, non-drinker and does not abuse drugs.

Allergies: She does not have any known allergies.

Patient Medications: IV antibiotics (specific name not mentioned)

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
General: The patient reported fever and severe swelling on the arm.
HEENT: Upon examination was revealed to be normal.
Respiratory: No issues related to breath. Negative for dyspnea. 
Cardiac: The patient did not report chest pain and cardiac rhythm is normal. 
Gastrointestinal/Genitourinary: Upon examination was found to be normal.
Hematic/Lymphatics: Known to have a proper blood clotting mechanism.
Neurologic: Normal. No history of a twin ischemic attack or cerebrovascular accident. 
Psychology: Mentally alert and conscious.
Skin: Redness, swelling, and increased warmth in the arm are confirmations of progressive cellulitis.

OBJECTIVE:

Vital signs: Stable at present but needs continuous monitoring due to the risk of progressing to sepsis.

General: Patient is alert, observant but in mild distress due to wound infection.
HEENT: Unremarkable findings. 
Respiratory: Regular breathwork. Effort is unlabored.
Cardiac: Stable heart rate and rhythm as per current vitals. PMI within normal limits.
Gastrointestinal: On examination, the abdomen is soft, non-tender with active bowel sounds.
Musculoskeletal: Patient may exhibit discomfort due to the stressful cellulitis arm wound. Strength is even in all extremities. 
Skin: Progressing cellulitis from the cat bite wound.
Neurological: Cranial nerves all grossly intact. No numbness or tingling present.

ASSESSMENT/PLAN: 

Based upon the lab reports confirming bacterial infection underlying cellulitis from the cat bite, high suspicion for sepsis is impending. Current treatment plan involves treating the bacterial infection and assessing the progress continuously. The antibiotics may need to be escalated if there's no improvement seen in a day or two.

ORDERS: 

Existing Medication: Continue the treatment with IV antibiotics. 

Follow-up: Arrange for a follow-up after 5-days to ensure effective recovery.

TREATMENT CALENDAR: Antibiotic Treatment started on 09/18/2023
notes.7: As Natalie's occupational therapist, my focus is to ensure recovery of her arm function as she recovers from the cellulitis caused by the cat bite. As the wound and potential for sepsis are being managed medically, my current role is to monitor and assess Natalie's ability to perform daily tasks and responsibilities, as well as the impact the pain and inflammation may be having on tasks such as writing, eating, working, and general arm-oriented tasks. We will pursue gentle techniques to maintain flexibility and strength in the affected arm as Natalie's condition improves and the medical team gives clearances for more extensive movements. Continued collaboration with the medical team is key to ensure our approach aligns with Natalie's overall health.v
notes.8:
INTERNAL MEDICINE CLINICAL NOTE:

Patient ID: Natalie Morgan is a 35-year-old female being seen for cellulitis progression from a cat bite and developing sepsis. 

Ms. Morgan reports that she was bitten by a stray cat three days ago and has observed her arm turning red, hot, and swollen. 

Her acute problem lies in the recent development of cellulitis from the cat bite, leading to a bacterial infection that places her at a rising risk for sepsis. 

Her medical treatments include administration of IV fluids for hydration and antibiotics to manage the infection.

History reflects no previous surgeries and no reported chronic illnesses. 

Family history is devoid of any known genetic disorders or health issues pertinent to the patient's current condition.

Her social history involves no use of tobacco, alcohol, or controlled substances. No known allergies have been reported. 

The latest immunization status of the patient is unchecked; however, none have been mentioned in the referring records.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Upon examination, the patient is normotensive and endured fever with severe swelling in the arm. All systemic evaluations, HEENT, Respiratory, Cardiac, Gastrointestinal, Genitourinary, Hematic/Lymphatics, and Neurologic, appeared normal with no remarkable findings.

Vital Signs: Vitals are currently stable, albeit continuous monitoring is highly recommended owing to the patient's sepsis risk.

PHYSICAL EXAM: 
Patient is alert, though showing clear signs of distress. The development of cellulitis on her arm is noticeable and escalating. All neurological signs are normal, including gross cranial nerves.

ASSESSMENT/PLAN:
Plan includes continuation of prescribed IV antibiotics and close monitoring. Should no improvement be seen within 48hrs, escalation of interventions may be necessary to inhibit the progression of the infection and a possible systemic septic reaction. 

FOLLOW UP: 
An in-person assessment after 5 days from the commencement of the antibiotic course (09/18/2023) is most prudent to reassess and ensure at-home compliance, observe progress, and reevaluate therapeutic modalities as required. 

Ms. Morgan demonstrated an understanding of the implications involved and agreed with the proposed plan. 

[This plan reflects the best endeavors to convey intention; however, the actual management plan may differ, ironically by documented findings.]
notes.9: Patient Natalie Morgan, aged 35, visited the ER following a bite by a stray cat that has resulted in cellulitis. Over a time span of three days, she observed increased inflammation in her arm, indicative of an infection. Clinical evaluation warranted suspicion of sepsis, solidified by laboratory findings that confirmed bacterial involvement. The case presented a high level of severity prompting the immediate implementation of a treatment plan involving IV fluids and antibiotics administration. To keep an eye on vital signs and ensure the effectiveness of the antibiotic treatment, the patient was admitted and is currently under continuous monitoring.

summary: Natalie Morgan, a 35-year-old woman, presented to the Emergency Department with a cat bite wound that had developed into cellulitis <Note ID:1>. She reported being bitten by a stray cat three days prior and subsequently noticed redness, swelling, and warmth in the affected area <Note ID:1>, <Note ID:3>. Ms. Morgan has no known medical history, allergies, or daily medications, and she leads a generally healthy lifestyle <Note ID:1>. Upon examination, her vital signs were stable, and she appeared comfortable, alert, and oriented <Note ID:1>. The wound on her arm showed signs of inflammation <Note ID:1>, <Note ID:3>. Laboratory tests confirmed a bacterial infection, raising concerns about the potential development of sepsis <Note ID:3>. As a result, she was started on intravenous (IV) antibiotics and fluids, and her condition is being continuously monitored <Note ID:1>, <Note ID:3>. The response to therapy is being evaluated daily, and her treatment plan may be adjusted based on her progress <Note ID:5>.
